awd_titl_txt: Exploiting dynamics and cell-to-cell variation in metabolic engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Cells can be engineered to produce products ranging from fuels to pharmaceuticals. However, the pathways that produce these products often reduce cell yields and increase costs. Turning these pathways on and off in some pattern might simultaneously reduce the burden and increase production.  Conceptually, this approach is similar to a work week and weekend. It is based on the idea that a combination of work and time off can result in higher overall productivity than sustained, constant effort. The research is complemented by educational and training opportunities for high school students and undergraduates. These students will be prepared to participate in a high-technology workforce.

Gene expression is noisy, leading to variation between cells in the absence of genetic diversity. Cells exploit that variability to optimize resource use. This calls into question whether introducing dynamics and noise in expression of genes could be beneficial. This project focuses on efflux pumps that export the monoterpene pinene. Pumps export toxic substrates and improve biosynthetic yields, but overexpressing them burdens the cell. Diversifying pump levels may allow populations to exploit these benefits and costs. The project is organized around two objectives: (1) to quantify single-cell differences in efflux and the duration of variability, and (2) to compare pinene production in strains with dynamic versus static pump expression. Time lapse microscopy coupled with microfluidics and quantitative image processing will be used to characterize pump variability. Pinene yields between strains with different approaches to pump expression will also be measured. Stochastic mathematical modeling to predict the impact of pump expression dynamics will complement the experiments. Overall, this project will test whether it is possible to exploit cell-to-cell variation in metabolic engineering to enhance production.

por.por_cntn:
Genetically identical cells commonly display different phenotypes. For example, bacteria that produce valuable chemicals or commodities may not all produce the same amount, exhibiting heterogeneity across the population. This diversity can be a byproduct of the fact that gene expression is an inherently noisy, stochastic process or it can be the result of regulatory pathways that increase diversity. Historically, studies quantifying cell-to-cell variability have focused on natural examples, such as identifying cases where populations exploit diversity for the purposes of bet-hedging or division of labor. However, cell-to-cell variability can also impact metabolically engineered cells. In natural contexts, cells exploit the stochastic nature of gene expression to diversify isogeneic populations and optimize resource utilization. This raises a fundamental question about whether noise in expression of genes involved in metabolic pathways could be beneficial in some contexts. Addressing this question requires both understanding the extent to which metabolically engineered cells exhibit heterogeneity and developing tools for controlling variability. This project contributed to our understanding of cell-to-cell heterogeneity and its impacts on metabolic engineering through several avenues of research.

We developed a new method for quantifying cell-to-cell heterogeneity in metabolically engineered strains that allowed for measurements of single-cell differences in production over time. The method uses an approach based on Stimulated Raman Scattering coupled with time-lapse microscopy. Chemical signatures of the cells can reveal information about production without the need for other types of readouts such as fluorescent reporters or dyes. Using this method, we measured cell-to-cell differences in production in several strains of bacteria that were engineered to overproduce free fatty acids. We found examples of strains with high levels of diversity in production across cells. We also found examples where production within colonies was uniform, but intracolony heterogeneity was high.

In addition, we developed two novel synthetic biology tools for controlling production and demonstrated their impact on strains engineered for improved biosynthesis. First, we developed decoy sites for transcription factors. These work as ?sponges? to sequester excess transcription factors, allowing for regulation of expression. Using arginine biosynthesis as a showcase, we observed a 16-fold increase in arginine production when we introduced the decoy system to steer metabolic flux towards increased arginine biosynthesis, with negligible growth differences compared to the wild type strain. Second, we focused on strains engineered to produce the cyclic terpene limonene and developed a system to transcriptionally regulate multiple steps within the limonene synthesis pathway. By altering expression of key genes in a pairwise fashion, this study revealed which enzymes were critical for driving limonene production. In both cases, these are examples of new tools that could be used to alter cell-to-cell heterogeneity by adjusting expression levels to compensate for cell-to-cell differences in transcription factor levels or through transcriptional tuning of enzyme levels to mitigate these effects.

In addition, in support of single-cell quantification methods, we developed a software tool that can segment and track the location of cells within microscopy images over time, dramatically increasing the amount of single-cell resolution data that it is possible to obtain. The software package, named DeLTA (Deep Learning for Time-lapse Analysis), uses a series of convolutional neural networks to segment and track individual bacteria growing within two-dimensional environments. The code is available open source on GitLab with extensive documentation and we also introduced a Google Colab notebook to allow users to run the software via a web-based interface.

The research accomplishments of the program were complemented by educational outreach activities. These included virtual presentations to kids in grades K-8 as part of the STEMentors series and involvement in the Education Working Group as part of the Engineering Biology Research Consortium. We also participated in outreach for high school students through the synthetic biology programs BioBuilder and iGEM. As part of this project, we hosted three undergraduate researchers in the lab and had four graduate students participate in the research program.
